value.name: ‘What we’re being told about Lockerbie is absolute nonsense from beginning to end’
value.description: Ever since Flora was killed on Pan Am Flight 103, Dr Jim Swire has been searching for answers – and says the FBI has the wrong man

value.name: Jeremy Hunt considering squeezing benefits while cutting inheritance tax
value.description: Ministers have already announced a fresh welfare crackdown amid efforts to get people back into work under a toughened sanctions scheme.

value.name: Transcript: Rebellions, reshuffles and Cameron’s return
value.description: Lucy Fisher So a week full of twists and turns got off to a pretty surprising start. The return of former Prime Minister David Cameron to cabinet, despite not currently having a seat in the House of Commons. Here’s how David, now Lord Cameron, described what he will bring to Rishi Sunak’s government.

value.name: Question Time Audience Member Suggests Puncturing Migrant Boats Using Drones
value.description: When presenter Fiona Bruce pointed out that it might be difficult to puncture the boats because it’s “a long coastline”, the audience member replied: “You see them on television, where there’s a drone and they’re watching everybody coming out…”

value.name: Gaza: Gillian Keegan says school protests 'unacceptable'
value.description: Hamas gunmen launched an unprecedented assault on Israel from the Gaza Strip on 7 October, killing about 1,200 people and taking more than 200 hostages. Israel responded with air strikes on Gaza and has launched a ground offensive. More than 12,000 people have been killed, according to the Hamas-run health ministry.

about.name: Timeline of the Syrian Civil War

value.name: Yousaf should be focusing on Scotland, not Gaza - Letters
value.description: While the domestic news has been dominated by Michael Matheson's iPad, a Herald reader says Humza Yousaf should be focusing less on Gaza

value.name: Northern Ireland Protocol: DUP waiting for government action on trading arrangement talks – Sir Jeffrey Donaldson
value.description: The DUP is awaiting action from the Government over long-running talks to address unionist concerns on post-Brexit trading arrangements.

value.name: Starmer suggests Gaza position is about readying Labour for government
value.description: He said Labour’s work with allies on the Israel-Hamas war was ‘what you would expect from someone who wants to’ be prime minister.

value.name: JANET STREET-PORTER: Watch out jungle, here comes Nasty Nigel! Ignore the whiners, Farage's rows with his Z-list campmates will be pure telly gold (and might just be bad news ...
value.description: What fun we'll have watching Nigel Farage explain the shortcomings of the single market and the EU to Danielle from East Enders or Nick from Hollyoaks.

value.name: Gaza: should global brands join the protests?
value.description: US doughnut chain Krispy Kreme has been involved in a humanitarian fundraiser for Palestinians in Gaza, putting itself on the same side as millions of protesters around the world. This might sound unsurprising in an era when global brands regularly align with popular causes, but virtually none has wanted to touch Gaza.

about.name: Timeline of the Syrian Civil War

video.name: Gaza: should global brands join the protests?

value.name: Unions present Tata with alternative plan aimed at saving jobs at steel plant
value.description: Unions have given steel giant Tata an alternative plan aimed at saving jobs at the biggest steel plant in the country. Tata Steel wants to decarbonise its site at Port Talbot in South Wales under moves to safeguard its future. Unions fear the plan would lead to around 3,000 job losses.

about.name: Copyright aspects of downloading and streaming

value.name: It’s the Year of the Pothole and Britain is crazy
value.description: Britain’s automotive association has appointed itself responsible for assigning the symbol of the year. And they’ve chosen potholes.

value.name: Blair is a divisive figure but his help on Middle East shows Starmer is serious
value.description: Hamas conflict may still be raging by the time of the next UK election, leaving Sir Keir with an inexperienced new cabinet, especially on foreign policy

value.name: A law saying Rwanda is safe doesn’t make it so
value.description: Letters: Readers take issue with Rishi Sunak’s plan for emergency legislation to allow asylum seekers to be sent to the African country after the supreme court ruled that it was unlawful

value.name: Tony Blair is acting as Keir Starmer’s Middle East broker
value.description: A TBI source stressed the organisation was non-political and would not formally second staff to ... The conflict is widely viewed as a foreign policy disaster for both the UK and US, lasting more than a decade and incurring massive humanitarian and ...

value.name: DUP waiting for action on trading arrangement talks – Sir Jeffrey Donaldson
value.description: The DUP is awaiting action from the Government over long-running talks to address unionist concerns on post-Brexit trading arrangements. Devolved government in Northern Ireland has been on hold for more than a year-and-a-half amid the DUP’s stand-off with ministers over new rules around the movement of goods to and from Great Britain.

value.name: Iceland is cancelling our Christmas ad for a very good reason
value.description: Back in 2018, our Rang-Tan advert, highlighting the dangers of palm oil and its impact on orangutans, fell foul of the UK’s rules on political advertising, and we were banned from airing it. So, we put it up online instead for the world to see and made ...

value.name: Humza Yousaf’s integrity on the line after SNP minister’s iPad ‘lie’, say Scottish Tories
value.description: Douglas Ross says First Minister 'has questions to answer' about Michael Matheson’s £11,000 roaming bill for parliamentary device

value.name: Liberia election results: Joseph Boakai on track to defeat George Weah
value.description: Opposition candidate Joseph Boakai has maintained a slim lead in the Liberian presidential election after the latest tranche of results were announced by the electoral commission. The 78-year-old political veteran has 50.89% of the votes, while incumbent President George Weah has 49.11%.

value.name: Labour MP Jo Stevens 'frightened' after graffiti sprayed on office following Gaza ceasefire vote
value.description: Shadow Welsh secretary Jo Stevens was among Labour MPs who abstained on a vote calling for an immediate ceasefire in Gaza.

value.name: Why Scotland needs a legal framework to protect its cultural heritage
value.description: From the island of St Kilda 40 miles west of the Hebrides, to Edinburgh’s splendid Georgian New Town, Scotland is a nation rich in cultural heritage, some of which is Unesco-protected. As well as the country’s globally renowned castles and monuments, Scotland has an enormous resource of intangible cultural heritage (ICH).

value.description: It feels as though every single week some part of the UK is being battered by storms and Bristol suffers a deluge of rain, and multiple parts of the South West flooded. In fact there hasn't been a single week since we launched this quiz where we haven't featured a weather-related question.

value.name: Starmer insists Labour united on alleviating Gaza suffering
value.description: Sir Keir Starmer said everyone in his party wanted to alleviate the suffering in Gaza, get the hostages released and stop civilians being caught in the conflict. Labour, he added, backed getting humanitarian aid into Gaza, and a way forward to a two-state solution.

value.name: Jeremy Hunt says businesses take ‘priority’ for tax cuts ahead of autumn statement
value.description: Jeremy Hunt has given his strongest indication yet that he is poised to cut taxes in next week’s mini-budget. The chancellor hinted that business levies would be slashed to boost the economy- and help fund the NHS - when he sets out his autumn statement on Wednesday.

video.name: Hunt says government ‘made it easier’ for BoE to bring down inflation

value.name: Politics latest news: No 10 won't rule out MPs working over Christmas on Sunak's Rwanda laws
value.description: Mark Harper insisted the Government is “confident” Rishi Sunak’s plan to save the Rwanda migrant policy will work despite Suella Braverman warning it will fail unless the Prime Minister is more radical .

value.description: Two boys, 12, in court charged with murder of teenager in Wolverhampton - Schoolboys were remanded into youth detention

value.name: U.S., UK, Norway Condemn Escalating Violence in Sudan's Darfur -Statement
value.description: WASHINGTON (Reuters) - The United States, United Kingdom and Norway on Friday condemned escalating violence and human rights abuses in Sudan, especially in the Darfur region, the three countries said in a statement.

value.name: Rishi Sunak denies 'tinkering' to save Rwanda plan
value.description: Rishi Sunak has denied "tinkering" with the government's Rwanda plan after his sacked former home secretary accused him of failing to take the radical action needed to implement the policy. The PM defended his plan to introduce emergency laws and a new treaty with Rwanda to save the plan after the Supreme Court ruled it was unlawful.
